Welcome to DIC toolbox’s documentation!¶

Contents: This toolbox is build to analysed output from 7D sofware

Post-7D treatment¶

correct7Dgdr¶

Warning

used this program on the data export using ‘txt>>gdr’ of the 7D version 0.9.5.178

This program correct the error in the output data from 7D version 0.9.5.178 were dy=-dy and exy=-exy

Example:>> run correct7Dgdr in the folder contening the output ‘.txt’

mean7Dgdr¶

This program is doing the mean of 7D output.

Note

please for each 7D analyses with different initial image create a folder as ‘IMG###’

Note

the mean data will be export in the folder allIMG

DIC Toolbox¶

Toolbox module

Created on 21 août 2015

Toolbox for data obtained using 7D software create by Pierre Vacher 7D software is software to perform Digital Image Correlation (DIC). This toolbox is used to analysed the data export from 7D software by using the exportation by ‘txt>>gdr’

Warning

In 7D version 0.9.5.178 there is a mistake during the expoprtation using ‘txt>>gdr’ dy=-dy and exy=-exy. Use ‘correct7Dgdr.py’ before using this toolbox

Note

if you want reduce the error due to the DIC process by doing the mean of multiple output, please refers to ‘mean7Dgdr.py’

@author: Thomas Chauve @contact: thomas.chauve@lgge.obs.ujf-grenoble.fr @license: CC-BY-CC

class dic.dic(adr_data, resolution, time_step, adr_micro=0)[source]¶

‘dic’ is a python class to analyse data from 2D digital image correlation

Note

this toolbox is build to work with the output from 7D using txt>>gdr export

__init__(adr_data, resolution, time_step, adr_micro=0)[source]¶
Parameters:
  • adr_data (str) – folder path where the 7D output are store
  • resolution (float) – pixel size of the image used for DIC (millimeters)
  • time_step (float) – time step between the picture (seconds)
  • adr_micro (str) – path for the black and white skeleton of the microstructure (bmp format) (default 0 - no microstructure)
__weakref__¶

list of weak references to the object (if defined)

Crop function to select the area of interest

Returns:

crop dic object
Return type:

dic
Exemple:
>>> data.crop()

Note

clic on the top left corner and bottom right corner to select the area

find_pic(strain_step=0.001)[source]¶

Find picture number as between 2 picture the increment of deformation is macro_strain

Parameters:strain_step (float) – macroscopic strain between 2 picture.
Returns:nb_img
Return type:array
movie(name, optdic=1, tl_img=0, vmin=nan, vmax=nan, vmin_i=nan, vmax_i=nan, colorbarcenter=False, colorbar=<matplotlib.colors.LinearSegmentedColormap object at 0x7fa617658ed0>, fps=5.0, nb_line=3, subarea=False)[source]¶
Parameters:
  • name – name of the output file ###.mp4
  • optdic (int) – 1=eqVonMises, 2=twod princitipal_strain, 3=eyy
  • tl_img (aita or dic) – top left image
  • vmin (float) – c axis minimum fig1
  • vmax (float) – c axis maximum fig1
  • vmin_i (float) – c axis minimum fig2
  • vmax_i (float) – c axis maximum fig2
  • colorbarcenter (bool) – do you want center the colorbar
  • colorbar (matplotlib.cm) – color of the colorbar
  • fps (int) – frame per second
  • nb_line (int) – number of line for the dic line (see function strain_macro)
  • subarea (bool) – Do you want select a sub area
Returns:

movie
Return type:

.mp4
noise_map()[source]¶

compute the variance of a set of map for u, v, exx, eyy, exy, eeq :return su,sv,sexx,seyy,sexy,seeq: :rtype su,sv,sexx,seyy,sexy,seeq: im2d.image2d

strain_macro(nb_line=3)[source]¶

Compute the macroscopic strain along the y-axis (vertical) using 2 methods :

(1)-mean of eyy

(2)-dic line (see Fanny Grennerat Thesis)

Parameters:

nb_line (int) – number of line skip at the top and bottom part of the picture during (2) evalutation
Returns:

macro_eyy, method (1)
Return type:

array
Returns:

macro_line, method (2)
Return type:

array
Returns:

time, time of each point (seconds)
Return type:

array
Exemple:
>>> [time,macro_eyy,macro_line]=data.strain_macro()
>>> plt.plot(time,macro_eyy)
>>> plt.show()

Warning

If you have macro_eyy~=-macro_line, it is because you did not correct the gdr output

symetricTensorMap¶

Created on 21 oct. 2015 This class defined map of symetric def positive tensor map.

@author: Thomas Chauve @contact: thomas.chauve@lgge.obs.ujf-grenoble.fr @license: CC-BY-CC

diag(twod=True)[source]¶

Diagonalisation of the symetricTensorMap

Parameters:twod (bool) – use a 2d symetric tensor (=> t33=t23=t13=0) (default True)
Returns:a, eigenvalue dim(3*n*m) where n*m is the dimension of the map (self.t11.field.shape)
Return type:array (3*n*m)
Returns:v, eigenvector dim(3*3*n*m) where n*m is the dimension of the map (self.t11.field.shape)
Return type:array (3*n*m)

Note

the eigenvector v(:,k,n,m) is associated to the eigenvalue a(k,n,m)

eqVonMises()[source]¶

Compute the Von Mises equivalent norm of the tensor

Returns:Von Mises equivalent norm (2/3*eij*eij)^0.5
Return type:image2d
eqtensor2d()[source]¶

Compute the equivalent norm of the tensor as it is a 2D mesurement

teq=sqrt(2/3*(t11^2+t22^2+2*t12^2))

Returns:equivalent norm as it is a 2d measurement
Return type:image2d

stress_contour(mask)[source]¶

image2d¶

Created on 3 juil. 2015

image2d is a class used to manipulate image under matrix shape and to do the analyses on the picture

Note

It has been build to manipulate both aita data and dic data

Warning

As all function are applicable to aita and dic data, please be careful of the meaning of what you are doing depending of the input data used !

@author: Thomas Chauve @contact: thomas.chauve@lgge.obs.ujf-grenoble.fr @license: CC-BY-CC

class image2d.image2d(field, resolution)[source]¶

image2d is a class for map of scalar data

Divide self by other case by case

Constructor : field is a matrix and resolution is the step size in mm

  • resolution (float) – step size resolution (millimeters)

Multiply case by case

__sub__(other)[source]¶

Subtract of 2 maps

auto_correlation(pad=1)[source]¶

Compute the auto-correlation function from Dumoulin 2003

Parameters:

pad (int) – padding with mean data (default 1)
Returns:

res_auto which the auto correlation function
Return type:

image2d
Returns:

Cinf see equation 6 Doumalin 2003
Return type:

float
Returns:

profil, it correspond to 180 profile taken for along line with direction between 0 and 180°. The profil[i,:] correspond to a line making an angle of i degree from x direction.
Return type:

np.array 180*length profile
Returns:

xi, it correspond to the distance along the profile for the variable profile
Return type:

np.array 180*length profile
Returns:

cross, it correspond to the length of the autocorrelation radius
Return type:

np.array dim=180
Exemple:
>>> # Using a fake image
>>> data=image2d.image2d(np.eye(200),1)
>>> [res_auto,Cinf,profil,xi,cross]=data.auto_correlation(pad=2)
>>> # plot the auto correlation function
>>> res_auto.plot()
>>>plt.show()
>>> # plot the auto_correlation radius in function of the angle of the profile
>>> plt.plot(cross)
>>> plt.xlabel('angle degree')
>>> plt.ylabel('auto correlation radius (mm)')
>>> plt.show()
>>> # extract the max and min auto correlation radius
>>> id=np.where(cross==np.min(cross))
>>> minC=id[0][0]
>>> id=np.where(cross==np.max(cross))
>>> maxC=id[0][0]
>>> ss=np.shape(xi) 
>>> CC=np.ones(ss[1])*Cinf
>>> plt.figure()
>>> plt.plot(xi[0,:],CC)
>>> plt.hold('on')
>>> plt.plot(xi[minC,:],profil[minC,:])
>>> plt.plot(xi[maxC,:],profil[maxC,:])
>>> plt.show()
diff(axis)[source]¶

Derive the image along the axis define

Parameters:axis (str) – ‘x’ to do du/dx or ‘y’ to do du/dy
Returns:differential of the map in respect to the ‘axis’ wanted
Return type:image2d

Warning

‘x’ axis is left to right and ‘y’ is bottom to top direction

mask_build(polygone=False, r=0, grainId=[], pos_center=0)[source]¶

Create a mask map with NaN value where you don’t want data and one were you want The default mask is a circle of center you choose and radius you define.

Parameters:
  • polygone (bool) – make a polygone mask (‘not yet implemented’)
  • r (float) – radius of the circle (warning what is the dimention of r mm ?)
  • grainId – You select the grainId you want in an array
Type:

array
Returns:

mask
Return type:

image2d
Returns:

vec (vector of grainId is selction by grain or pos_center if selection by circle or 0 if polygone )
Return type:

array

Note

if you want applied a mask one your data just do data*mask where data is an image2d object
